div.p: AN ACCOUNT OF THE REMARKABLE OCCURRENCES IN THE LIFE AND TRAVELS OF COL. JAMES SMITH, (Now a Citizen of Bourbon County, Kentucky) DURING HIS CAPTIVITY WITH THE INDIANS, IN THE YEARS 1755, '56, '57, '58, & '59, In which the Cu≈øtoms, Manners, Traditions, Theological Sentiments, Mode of Warfare, Military Tactics, Di≈øcipline and Encampments, Treatment of pri≈øoners, &c. are better explained, and more minutely related, than has been heretofore done, by any author on that ≈øubject. Together with a De≈øcription of the Soil, Timber and Waters, where he travelled with the Indians, during his captivity.

TO WHICH IS ADDED, A Brief Account of ≈øome Very Uncommon Occurrences, which tran≈øpired after his return from captivity; as well as of the Different Campaigns carried on again≈øt the Indians to the we≈øtward of Fort Pitt, ≈øince the year 1755, to the pre≈øent date.
WRITTEN BY HIMSELF.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: I WAS ≈øtrongly urged to publi≈øh the following work, immediately after my return from captivity, which was nearly forty years ago‚Äîbut, as at that time the Americans were ≈øo little acquainted with Indian affairs, I apprehended a great part of it would be viewed as fable or romance.

As the Indians never attempted to prevent me either from reading or writing, I kept a Journal, which I revi≈øed ≈øhortly after my return from captivity, and which I have kept ever ≈øince: and as I have had but a moderate Engli≈øh education, have been advi≈øed to employ ≈øome per≈øon of liberal education to tran≈øcribe and embelli≈øh it‚Äîbut believing that nature always out≈øhines art, have thought, that occurrences truly and plainly ≈øtated, as they happened, would make the be≈øt hi≈øtory, be better under≈øtood, and mo≈øt entertaining.

In the different Indian ≈øpeeches copied into this work, I have not only imitated their own ≈øtyle, or mode of ≈øpeaking, but have al≈øo pre≈øerved the ideas meant to be communicated in tho≈øe ≈øpeeches ‚ÄîIn common conver≈øation, I have u≈øed my own ≈øtyle, but pre≈øerved their ideas. The principal advantage that I expect will re≈øult to the public, from the publication of the following ≈øheets, is the observations on the Indian mode of warfare. Experience has taught the Americans the nece≈ø≈øity of adopting their mode, and the more perfect we are in that mode, the better we ≈øhall be able to defend our≈øelves again≈øt them, when defence is nece≈ø≈øary,

div.head: REMARKABLE OCCURRENCES, &c.
div.p: IN May 1755, the province of Penn≈øylvania, agreed to ≈øend out three hundred men, in order to cut a waggon road from Fort Loudon, to join Braddock's road, near the Turkey Foot, or three forks of Yohogania; My brother-in-law, William Smith e≈øq. of Conococheague, was appointed commi≈ø≈øioner, to have the over≈øight of the≈øe road-cutters.

Though I was at that time only eighteen years of age, I had fallen violently in love with a young lady, whom I apprehended was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a large ≈øhare of both beauty and virtue;‚Äî but being born between Venus and Mars, I concluded I mu≈øt al≈øo leave my dear fair one, and go out with this company of road-cutters, to ≈øee the event of this campaign; but ≈øtill expecting that ≈øome time in the cour≈øe of this ≈øummer, I ≈øhould again return to the arms of my beloved.

We went on with the road, without interruption, until near the Allegheny Mountain; when I was ≈øent back, in order to hurry up ≈øome provi≈øion waggons that were on the way after us; I proceeded down the road as far as the cro≈ø≈øings of Juniata, where, finding the waggons were coming on as fa≈øt as po≈ø≈øible, I returned up the road, again towards the Allegheny Mountain, in company with one Arnold Vigoras. About four or five miles above Bedford, three Indians had made a blind of bu≈øhes, ≈øtuck in the ground, as though they grew naturally, where they concealed them≈øelves, about fifteen yards from the road. When we came oppo≈øite to them, they fired upon us, at this ≈øhort di≈øtance, and killed my fellow traveller, yet their bullets did not touch me; but my hor≈øe making a violent ≈øtart, threw me, and the Indians immediately ran up, and took me pri≈øoner. The one that laid hold on me was a Cana≈øatauga, the other two were Delawares. One of them could ≈øpeak Engli≈øh, and a≈øked me if there were any more white men coming
after? I told them not any near, that I knew of. Two of the≈øe Indians ≈øtood by me, whil≈øt the other ≈øcalped my comrade: they then ≈øet off and ran at a ≈ømart rate, through the woods, for about fifteen miles, and that night we ≈ølept on the Alegheny Mountain, without fire.

The next morning they divided the la≈øt of their provi≈øion which they had brought from Fort DuQue≈øne, and gave me an equal ≈øhare, which was about two or three ounces of mouldy bi≈øcuit‚Äîthis and a young Ground-Hog, about as large as a Rabbit, roa≈øted, and al≈øo equally divided, was all the provi≈øion we had until we came to the Loyal-Hannan, which was about fifty miles; and a great part of the way we came through exceeding rocky Laurel-thickets, without any path. When we came to the We≈øt ≈øide of Laurel-Hill, they gave the ≈øcalp halloo, as u≈øual, which is a long yell or halloo, for every ≈øcalp or pri≈øoner they have in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; the la≈øt of the≈øe ≈øcalp halloos were followed with quick and ≈øudden, ≈øhrill ≈øhouts of joy and triumph. On their performing this, we were an≈øwered by the firing of a number of guns on the Loyal-Hannan, one after another, quicker than one could count, by another party of Indians, who were encamped near where Ligoneer now ≈øtands. As we advanced near this party, they increa≈øed with repeated ≈øhouts of joy and triumph; but I did not ≈øhare with them in their exce≈ø≈øive mirth. When we came to this camp, we found they had plenty of Turkeys and other meat, there; and though I never before eat veni≈øon without bread or ≈øalt; yet as I was hungry, it reli≈øhed very well. There we lay that night, and the next morning the whole of us marched on our way for Fort DuQue≈øne. The night after we joined another camp of Indians, with nearly the ≈øame ceremony, attended with great noi≈øe, and apparent joy, among all, except one. The next morning we continued our march, and in the afternoon we came in full view of the fort, which ≈øtood on the point, near where Fort Pitt now ≈øtands. We then made a halt on the bank of the Alegheny, and repeated the ≈øcalp halloo, which was an≈øwered by the firing of all the firelocks in the hands of both Indians and French who were in and about the fort, in the afore≈øaid manner, and al≈øo the great guns, which were followed by the continued ≈øhouts and yells of the different ≈øavage tribes who were then collected there.

As I was at this time unacquainted with this mode of firing and yelling of the ≈øavages, I concluded that there were thou≈øands of Indians there, ready to receive General Braddock; but what added to my ≈øurprize, I ≈øaw numbers running towards me, ≈øtripped naked, excepting breech-clouts, and painted in the mo≈øt hideous manner, of various colors, though the principal
color was vermillion, or a bright red; yet there was annexed to this, black, brown, blue, &c. As they approached, they formed them≈øelves into two long ranks, about two or three rods apart. I was told by an Indian that could ≈øpeak Engli≈øh, that I mu≈øt run betwixt the≈øe ranks, and that they would flog me all the way, as I ran, and if I ran quick, it would be ≈øo much the better, as they would quit when I got to the end of the ranks. There appeared to be a general rejoicing around me, yet, I could find nothing like joy in my brea≈øt; but I ≈øtarted to the race with all the re≈øolution and vigor I was capable of exerting, and found that it was as I had been told, for I was flogged the whole way. When I had got near the end of the lines, I was ≈øtruck with ≈øomething that appeared to me to be a ≈øtick, or the handle of a tommahawk, which cau≈øed me to fall to the ground. On my recovering my ≈øen≈øes, I endeavored to renew my race; but as I aro≈øe, ≈øome one ca≈øt ≈øand in my eyes, which blinded me ≈øo, that I could not ≈øee where to run. They continued beating me mo≈øt intolerably, until I was at length in≈øen≈øible; but before I lo≈øt my ≈øen≈øes, I remember my wi≈øhing them to ≈øtrike the fatal blow, for I thought they intended killing me, but apprehended they were too long about it.

The fir≈øt thing I remember was my being in the fort, amid≈øt the French and Indians, and a French doctor ≈øtanding by me, who had opened a vein in my left arm: after which the interpreter a≈øked me how I did, I told him I felt much pain; the doctor then wa≈øhed my wounds, and the brui≈øed places of my body, with French brandy. As I felt faint, and the brandy ≈ømelt well, I a≈øked for ≈øome inwardly, but the doctor told me, by the interpreter, that it did not ≈øuit my ca≈øe.

When they found I could ≈øpeak, a number of Indians came around me, and examined me with threats of cruel death, if I did not tell the truth. The fir≈øt que≈øtion they a≈øked me, was, how many men were there in the party that were coming from Penn≈øylvania, to join Braddock? I told them the truth, that there were three hundred. The next que≈øtion was, were they well armed? I told them them they were all well armed, (meaning the arm of fle≈øh) for they had only about thirty guns among the whole of them; which, if the Indians had known, they would certainly have gone and cut them all off‚ñ™ therefore I could not in con≈øcience let them know the defencele≈øs ≈øituation of the≈øe road-cutters. I was then ≈øent to the ho≈øpital, and carefully attended by the doctors, and recovered quicker than what I expected.

Some time after I was there, I was vi≈øited by the Delaware Indian already mentioned, who was at the taking of me, and could ≈øpeak ≈øome Engli≈øh. Though he ≈øpoke but bad Engli≈øh,
yet I found him to be a man of con≈øiderable under≈øtanding. I a≈øked him if I had done any thing that had offended the Indians, which cau≈øed them to treat me ≈øo unmercifully? He ≈øaid no, it was only an old cu≈øtom the Indians had, and it was like how do you do; after that he ≈øaid I would be well u≈øed. I a≈øked him if I ≈øhould be admitted to remain with the French? He ≈øaid no ‚Äîand told me that as ≈øoon as I recovered, I mu≈øt not only go with the Indians, but mu≈øt be made an Indian my≈øelf. I a≈øked him what news from Braddock's army? He ≈øaid the Indians ≈øpied them every day, and he ≈øhewed me by making marks on the ground with a ≈øtick, that Braddock's army was advancing in very clo≈øe order, and that the Indians would ≈øurround them, take trees, and (as he expre≈ø≈øed it) shoot um down all one pigeon.

Shortly after this, on the 9th day of July 1755, in the morning I heard a great ≈øtir in the fort. As I could then walk with a ≈øtaff in my hand, I went out of the door which was ju≈øt by the wall of the fort, and ≈øtood upon the wall and viewed the Indians in a huddle before the gate, where were barrels of powder, bullets, flints &c. and every one taking what ≈øuited; I ≈øaw the Indians al≈øo march off in rank, intire‚Äîlikewi≈øe the French Canadians, and ≈øome regulars, after viewing the Indians and French in different po≈øitions, I computed them to be about four hundred, and wondered that they attempted to go out again≈øt Braddock with ≈øo ≈ømall a party. I was then in high hopes that I would ≈øoon ≈øee them flying before the Briti≈øh troops, and that general Braddock would take the fort and re≈øcue me.

I remained anxious to know the event of this day; and in the afternoon I again ob≈øerved a great noi≈øe and commotion in the fort, and though at that time I could not under≈øtand French, yet I found that it was the voice of Joy and triumph, and feared that they had received what I called bad news.

I had ob≈øerved ≈øome of the old country ≈øoldiers ≈øpeak Dutch, as I ≈øpoke Dutch I went to one of them, and a≈øked him what was the news? he told me that a runner had ju≈øt arrived, who ≈øaid that Braddock would certainly be defeated; that the Indians and French had ≈øurrounded him, and were concealed behind trees and in gullies, and kept a con≈øtant fire upon the Engli≈øh, and that they ≈øaw the Engli≈øh falling in heaps, and if they did not take the river which was the only gap, and make their e≈øcape, there would not be one man left alive before ≈øun down. Some time after this I heard a number of ≈øcalp halloo's and ≈øaw a company of Indians and French coming in. I ob≈øerved they had a great many bloody ≈øcalps, grenadiers' caps, Briti≈øh canteens, bayonets &c. with them. They brought the news that Braddock was defeated. After that another company came in which appeared
to be about one hundred, and chiefly Indians, and it ≈øeemed to me that almo≈øt every one of this company was carrying ≈øcalps; after this came another company with a number of waggon-hor≈øes, and al≈øo a great many ≈øcalps. Tho≈øe that were coming in, and tho≈øe that had arrived, kept a con≈øtant firing of ≈ømall arms, and al≈øo the great guns in the fort, which were accompanied with the mo≈øt hedious ≈øhouts and yells from all quarters; ≈øo that it appeared to me as if the infernal regions had broke loo≈øe.

About ≈øun down I beheld a ≈ømall party coming in with about a dozen pri≈øoners, ≈øtripped naked, with their hands tied behind their backs, and their faces, and part of their bodies blacked‚Äî the≈øe pri≈øoners they burned to death on the bank of Alegheny River oppo≈øite to the fort. I ≈øtood on the fort wall until I beheld them begin to burn one of the≈øe men, they had him tied to a ≈øtake and kept touching him with fire-brands, red-hod irons &c. and he ≈øcreeming in a mo≈øt doleful manner,‚Äîthe Indians in the mean time yelling like infernal ≈øpirits. As this ≈øcene appeared too ≈øhocking for me to behold, I retired to my lodging both ≈øore and ≈øorry.

When I came into my longings I ≈øaw Ru≈ø≈øel's Seven Sermons, which they had brought from the field of battle, which a Frenchman made a pre≈øent of to me. From the be≈øt information I could receive there were only ≈øeven Indians and four French killed in this battle, and five hundred Briti≈øh lay dead in the field; be≈øides what were killed in the river on their retreat.

The morning after the battle I ≈øaw Braddock's artilery brought into the fort, the ≈øame day I al≈øo ≈øaw ≈øeveral Indians in Briti≈øh-officers' dre≈øs with ≈øa≈øh, half-moon, laced hats &c. which the Briti≈øh then wore.

A few days after this the Indians demanded me and I was obliged to go with them. I was not yet well able to march, but they took me in a canoe, up the Alegheny River to an Indian town that was on the north ≈øide of the river, about forty miles above Fort DuQue≈øne. Here I remained about three weeks, and was then taken to an Indian town on the we≈øt branch of Mu≈økingum, about twenty miles above the forks, which was called Tullihas, inhabited by Delawares, Caughnewagos and Mohicans.‚ÄîOn our rout betwixt the afore≈øaid towns, the country was chiefly black-oak and white-oak land, which appeared generally to be good wheat land, chiefly ≈øecond and third rate, intermixed with ≈øome rich bottoms.

The day after my arrival at the afore≈øaid town, a number of Indians collected about me, and one of them began to pull the hair out of my head. He had ≈øome a≈øhes on a piece of
bark, in which he frequently dipped his fingers in order to take the firmer hold, and ≈øo he went on, as if he had been plucking a turkey, until he had all the hair clean out of my head, except a ≈ømall ≈øpot about three or four inches ≈øquare on my crown; this they cut off with a pair of ≈øci≈ø≈øors, excepting three locks, which they dre≈ø≈øed up in their own mode. Two of the≈øe they wraped round with a narrow beaded garter made by them≈øelves for that purpo≈øe, and the other they platted at full length, and then ≈øtuck it full of ≈øilver broches. After this they bored my no≈øe and ears, and fixed me off with ear rings and no≈øe jewels, then they ordered me to ≈øtrip off my clothes and put on a breech-clout, which I did; they then painted my head, face and body in various colours. They put a large belt of wampom on my neck, and ≈øilver bands on my hands and right arm; and ≈øo an old chief led me out in the ≈øtreet and gave the alarm halloo, coo-wigh, ≈øeveral times repeated quick, and on this all that were in the town came running and ≈øtood round the old chief, who held me by the hand in the mid≈øt.‚Äî As I at that time knew nothing of their mode of adoption, and had ≈øeen them put to death all they had taken, and as I never could find that they ≈øaved a man alive at Braddock's defeat, I made no doubt but they were about putting me to death in ≈øome cruel manner. The old chief holding me by the hand made a long ≈øpeech very loud, and when he had done he handed me to three young ≈øquaws, who led me by the hand down the bank into the river until the water was up to our middle. The ≈øquaws then made ≈øigns to me to plunge my≈øelf into the water, but I did not under≈øtand them; I thought that the re≈øult of the council was that I ≈øhould be drowned, and that the≈øe young ladies were to be the executioners. They all three laid violent hold of me, and I for ≈øome time oppo≈øed them with all my might, which occa≈øioned loud laughter by the multitude that were on the bank of the river. At length one of the ≈øquaws made out to ≈øpeak a little Engli≈øh (for I believe they began to be afraid of me) and ≈øaid, no hurt you; on this I gave my≈øelf up to their lady≈øhips, who were as good as their word; for though they plunged me under water, and wa≈øhed and rubbed me ≈øeverely, yet I could not ≈øay they hurt me much.

The≈øe young women then led me up to the council hou≈øe, where ≈øome of the tribe were ready with new cloths for me. They gave me a new ruffled ≈øhirt, which I put on, al≈øo a pair of leggins done off with ribbons and beads, likewi≈øe a pair of mocka≈øons, and garters dre≈ø≈øed with beads, Porcupine-quills, and redhair‚Äîal≈øo a tin≈øel laced cappo. They again painted my head and face with various colors, and tied a bunch of red feathers to one of the≈øe locks they had left on the crown of
my head, which ≈øtood up five or ≈øix inches. They ≈øeated me on a bear ≈økin, and gave me a pipe, tomakawk, and polecat ≈økin pouch, which had been ≈økined pocket fa≈øhion, and contained tobacco, killegenico, or dry ≈øumach leaves, which they mix with their tobacco,‚Äîal≈øo ≈øpunk, flint and ≈øteel. When I was thus ≈øeated, the Indians came in dre≈ø≈øed and painted in their grande≈øt manner. As they came in they took their ≈øeats and for a con≈øiderable time there was a profound ≈øilence, every one was ≈ømoking,‚Äîbut not a word was ≈øpoken among them.‚ÄîAt length one of the chiefs made a ≈øpeech which was delivered to me by an interpretor,‚Äîand was as followeth:‚Äî"My ≈øon, you are now fle≈øh of our fle≈øh, and bone of our bone. By the ceremony which was performed this day, every drop of white blood was wa≈øhed out of your veins; you are taken into the Caughnewago nation, and initiated into a warlike tribe; you are adopted into a great family, and now received with great ≈øeriousne≈øs and ≈øolemnity in the room and place of a great man; after what has pa≈ø≈øed this day, you are now one of us by an old ≈øtrong law and cu≈øtom‚ÄîMy ≈øon, you have now nothing to fear, we are now under the ≈øame obligations to love, ≈øupport and defend you, that we are to love and defend one another, therefore you are to con≈øider your≈øelf as one of our people."‚ÄîAt this time I did not believe this fine ≈øpeech, e≈øpecially that of the white blood being wa≈øhed out of me; but ≈øince that time I have found that there was much ≈øincerity in ≈øaid ≈øpeech,‚Äîfor from that day I never knew them to make any di≈øtinction between me and them≈øelves in any re≈øpect whatever until I left them.‚ÄîIf they had plenty of cloathing I had plenty, if we were ≈øcarce we all ≈øhared one fate.

When they ≈øaw the number of them that were confined in the water above the tree, the young Indians ran back to the town, and in a ≈øhort time returned with their ≈øpears, giggs, bows and arrows, &c. and were the chief of that day engaged in killing rock-fi≈øh, in≈øomuch that we had more than we could u≈øe or pre≈øerve. As we had no ≈øalt, or any way to keep them, they lay upon the banks, and after ≈øome time great numbers of turkey-buzzards and eagles collected together and devoured them.
Shortly after this we left Sunyendeand, and in three days arrived at Detroit, where we remained this ≈øummer.

Some time in May we heard that General Forbes, with ≈øeven thou≈øand men was preparing to carry on a campaign again≈øt Fort DuQue≈øne, which then ≈øtood near where Fort Pitt was afterwards erected. Upon receiving this news a number of runners were ≈øent off by the French commander at Detroit, to urge the different tribes of Indian warriors to repair to Fort DuQue≈øne.

Some time in July 1758, the Ottowas, Jibewas, Potowatomies and Wiandots rendzvouzed at Detroit, and marched off to Fort DuQue≈øne, to prepare for the encounter of General Forbes. The common report was, that they would ≈øerve him as they did General Braddock, and obtain much plunder. From this time, until fall, we had frequent accounts of Forbes's army, by Indian runners that were ≈øent out to watch their motion. They ≈øpied them frequently from the mountains ever after they left Fort Loudon. Notwith≈øtanding their vigilence, colonel Grant with his Highlanders ≈øtole a march upon them, and in the night took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a hill about eighty rod from Fort DuQue≈øne:‚Äîthis hill is on that account called Grant's hill to this day. The French and Indians knew not that Grant and his men were there until they beat the drum and played upon
the bagpipes, ju≈øt at day-light. They then flew to arms, and the Indians ran up under covert of the banks of Allegheny and Monoagahela, for ≈øome di≈øtance, and then ≈øallied out from the banks of the rivers, and took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the hill above Grant; and as he was on the point of it in ≈øight of the fort, they immediately ≈øurrounded him, and as he had his Highlanders in ranks, and very clo≈øe order, and the Indians ≈øcattered, and concealed behind trees, they defeated him with the lo≈øs only of a few warriors:‚Äîmo≈øt of the Highlanders were killed or taken pri≈øoners.

After this defeat the Indians held a council, but were divided in their opinions. Some ≈øaid that general Forbes would now turn back, and go home the way that he came, as Dunbar had done when General Braddock was defeated: others ≈øuppo≈øed he would come on. The French urged the Indians to ≈øtay and ≈øee the event:‚Äîbut as it was hard for the Indians to be ab≈øent from their ≈øquaws and children, at this ≈øea≈øon of the year, a great many of them returned home to their hunting. After this, the remainder of the Indians, ≈øome French regulars, and a number of Canadians, marched off in que≈øt of General Forbes. They met his army near Fort Ligoneer, and attacked them, but were fru≈øtrated in their de≈øign. They ≈øaid that Forbes's men were beginning to learn the art of war, and that there were a great number of American riflemen along with the read-coats, who ≈øcattered out, took trees, and were good marks-men; therefore they found they could not accompli≈øh their de≈øign, and were obliged to retreat. When they returned from the battle to Fort DuQue≈øne, the Indians conclued that they would go to their hunting. The French endeavored to per≈øuade them to ≈øtay and try another battle. The Indians ≈øaid if it was only the red-coats they had to do with, they could ≈øoon ≈øubdue them, but they could not with≈øtand Asbalecoa, or the Great Knife, which was the name they gave the Virginians. They then returned home to their hunting, and the French evacuated the fort, which General Forbes came and took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of without further oppo≈øition, late in the year 1758, and at this time began to build Fort Pitt.

When Tecaughretanego had heard the particulars of Grant's defeat, he ≈øaid that he could not well account for his contradictory and incon≈øi≈øtent conduct. He ≈øaid as the art of war con≈øi≈øts in ambu≈øhing and ≈øurprizing our enemies, and in preventing them from ambu≈øhing and ≈øurprizing us; Grant, in the fir≈øt place, acted like a wi≈øe and experienced officer, in artfully approaching in the night without being di≈øcovered; but when he came to the place, and the Indians were lying a≈øleep out≈øide of the fort, between him and the Allegheny river, in place of ≈ølipping up quietly, and falling upon them with their
broad ≈øwords, they beat the drums and played upon the bagpipes. He ≈øaid he could account for this incon≈øi≈øtent conduct no other way than by ≈øuppo≈øing that he had made too free with ≈øpirituous liquors during the night, and became intoxicated about day-light. But to return:

This year we hunted up Sandu≈øky, and down Sciota, and took nearly the ≈øame route that we had done the la≈øt hunting ≈øea≈øon. We had con≈øiderable ≈øucce≈øs, and returned to Detroit ≈øome time in April 1759.

Shortly after this, Tecaughretanego, his ≈øon Nungany and my≈øelf, went from Detroit, (in an elm bark canoe) to Caughnewaga, a very ancient Indian town, about nine miles above Montreal, where I remained until about the fir≈øt of July. I then heard of a French ≈øhip at Montreal that had Engli≈øh pri≈øoners on board, in order to carry them over ≈øea, and exchange them. I went privately off from the Indians, and got al≈øo on board; but as general Wolfe had ≈øtopped the River St. Laurence, we were all ≈øent to pri≈øon in Montreal, where I remained four months. Some time in November we were all ≈øent off from this place to Crown Point, and exchanged.

Early in the year 1760, I came home to Canacocheague, and found that my people could never a≈øcertain whether I was killed or taken, until my return. They received me with great joy, but were ≈øurprized to ≈øee me ≈øo much like an Indian, both in my gait and ge≈øture.

Upon enquiry, I found that my ≈øweet-heart was married a few days before I arrived. My feelings I mu≈øt leave on this occa≈øion, for tho≈øe of my readers to judge, who have felt the pangs of di≈øappointed love, as it is impo≈ø≈øible now for me to de≈øcribe the emotion of ≈øoul I felt at that time.

Now there was peace with the Indians which la≈øted until the year 1763. Sometime in May, this year, I married, and about that time the Indians again commenced ho≈øtilities, and were bu≈øily engaged in killing and ≈øcalping the frontier inhabitants in various parts of Penn≈øylvania. The whole Conococheague Valley, from the North to the South Mountain, had been almo≈øt entirely evacuated during Braddock's war. This ≈øtate was then a Quaker government, and at the fir≈øt of this war the frontiers received no a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from the ≈øtate. As the people were now beginning to live at home again, they thought hard to be drove away a ≈øecond time, and were determined if po≈ø≈øible, to make a ≈øtand: therefore they rai≈øed as much money by collections and ≈øub≈øcriptions, as would pay a company of rifle-men for ≈øeveral months. The ≈øub≈øcribers met and elected a committee to manage the bu≈øine≈øs. The committee appointed me captain of this company of rangers, and gave me the appointment
of my ≈øubalterns. I cho≈øe two of the mo≈øt active young men that I could find, who had al≈øo been long in captivity with the Indians. As we enli≈øted our men, we dre≈ø≈øed them uniformly in the Indian manner, with breech-clouts, leggins, mocke≈øons and green ≈øhrouds, which we wore in the ≈øame manner that the Indians do, and nearly as the Highlanders wear their plaids. In place of hats we wore red hankerchiefs, and painted our faces red and black, like Indian warriors. I taught them the Indian di≈øcipline, as I knew of no other at that time, which would an≈øwer the purpo≈øe much better than Briti≈øh. We ≈øucceeded beyond expectation in defending the frontiers, and were extolled by our employers. Near the conclu≈øion of this expedition I accepted of an en≈øign's commi≈ø≈øion in the regular ≈øervice, under King George, in what was then called the Penn≈øylvania line. Upon my re≈øignation, my lieutenant ≈øucceeded me in command, the re≈øt of the time they were to ≈øerve. In the fall (the ≈øame year) I went on the Su≈øquehannah campaign, again≈øt the Indians, under the command of General Arm≈øtrong. In this route we burnt the Delaware and Mon≈øey towns, on the We≈øt Branch of the Su≈øquehannah, and de≈øtroyed all their corn.

In the year 1764, I received a lieutenant's commi≈ø≈øion, and went out on General Bouquet's campaign again≈øt the Indians on the Mu≈økingum. Here we brought them to terms, and promi≈øed to be at peace with them, upon condition that they would give up all our people that they had then in captivity among them. They then delivered unto us three hundred of the pri≈øoners, and ≈øaid that they could not collect them all at this time, as it was now late in the year, and they were far ≈øcattered; but they promi≈øed that they would bring them all into Fort Pitt early next ≈øpring, and as ≈øecurity that they would do this, they delivered to us ≈øix of their chiefs, as ho≈øtages. Upon this we ≈øettled a ce≈ø≈øation of arms for ≈øix months, and promi≈øed upon their fulfilling the afore≈øaid condition, to make with them a permanent peace.

A little below Fort Pitt the ho≈øtages all made their e≈øcape. Shortly after this the Indians ≈øtole hor≈øes, and killed ≈øome people on the frontiers. The king's proclamation was then circulating and ≈øet up in various public places, prohibiting any per≈øon from trading with the Indians, until further orders.

Notwith≈øtanding all this, about the fir≈øt of March 1765, a number of waggons loaded with Indian goods, and warlike ≈øtores, were ≈øent from Philadelphia to Henry Pollens's, Conococheague, and from thence ≈øeventy pack-hor≈øes were loaded with the≈øe goods, in order to carry them to Fort Pitt. This alarmed the country, and Mr. William Duffield rai≈øed about
fifty armed men, and met the pack-hor≈øes at the place where Mercer≈øburg now ≈øtands. Mr. Duffield de≈øired the employers to ≈øtore up their goods, and not proceed until further orders. They made light of this, and went over the North Mountain, where they lodged in a ≈ømall valley called the Great Cove. Mr. Duffield and his party followed after, and came to their lodging, and again urged them to ≈øtore up their goods:‚ÄîHe rea≈øoned with them on the impropriety of their proceedings, and the great danger the frontier inhabitants would be expo≈øed to, if the Indians ≈øhould now get a ≈øupply:‚ÄîHe ≈øaid as it was well known that they had ≈øcarcely any amunition, and were almo≈øt naked, to ≈øupply them now, would be a kind of murder, and would be illegally trading at the expence of the blood and trea≈øure of the frontiers. Notwith≈øtanding his powerful rea≈øoning, the≈øe traders made game of what he ≈øaid, and would only an≈øwer him by ludicrous burle≈øque.

When I beheld this, and found that Mr. Duffield would not compel them to ≈øtore up their goods, I collected ten of my old warriors, that I had formerly di≈øciplined in the Indian way, went off privately, after night, and encamped in the woods. The next day, as u≈øual, we blacked and painted, and waylayed them near Sidelong Hill. I ≈øcattered my men about forty rod along the ≈øide of the road and ordered every two to take a tree, and about eight or ten rod between each couple, with orders to keep a re≈øerve fire, one not to fire until his comrade had loaded his gun‚Äîby this means we kept up a con≈øtant, ≈ølow fire, upon them from front to rear:‚ÄîWe then heard nothing of the≈øe trader's merriment or burle≈øque. When they ≈øaw their pack-hor≈øes falling clo≈øe by them, they called out pray gentlemen, what would you have us to do? The reply was, collect all your loads to the front, and unload them in one place; take your private property, and immediately retire. When they were gone, we burnt what they left, which con≈øi≈øted of blankets, ≈øhirts, vermillion, lead, beads, wampum, tomahawks, ≈øcalping knives, &c.

The traders went bach to Fort Loudon, and applied to the commanding officer there, and got a party of Highland ≈øoldiers, and went with them in que≈øt of the robbers, as they called us, and without applying to a magi≈øtrate, or obtaining any civil authority, but barely upon ≈øu≈øpicion, they took a number of creditable per≈øons pri≈øoners, (who were chiefly not any way concerned in this action) and confined them in the guard-hou≈øe in Fort Loudon. I then rai≈øed three hundred riflemen, marched to Fort Loudon, and encamped on a hill in ≈øight of the fort. We were not long there, until we had more than double as many of the Briti≈øh troops pri≈øoners in our camp, as they had of
our people in the guard-hou≈øe. Captain Grant, a Highland officer, who command Fort Loudon, then ≈øent a flag of truce to our camp, where we ≈øettled a cartel, and gave them above two for one, which enabled us to redeem all our men from the guard-hou≈øe, without further difficulty.

After this Captain Grant kept a number of rifle guns, which the Highlanders had taken from the country people, and refu≈øed to give them up. As he was riding out one day, we took him pri≈øoner, and detained him until he delivered up the arms; we al≈øo de≈øtroyed a large quantity of gun-powder that the traders had ≈øtored up, le≈øt it might be conveyed privately to the Indians. The king's troops, and our party, had now got entirely out of the channel of the civil law, and many unju≈øtifiable things were done by both parties. This convinced me more than ever I had been before, of the ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of the civil law, in order to govern mankind.
About this time the following ≈øong was compo≈øed by Mr. George Campbell (an Iri≈øh gentleman, who had been educated in Dublin) and was frequently ≈øung to the tune of the Black Joke:

lg.l: Ye patriot ≈øouls who love to ≈øing,
What ≈øerves your country and your king,
In wealth, peace and royal e≈øtate;
Attention give whil≈øt I rehear≈øe,

How party intere≈øt ≈øtrove what it cou'd,
To profit it≈øelf by public blood,
But ju≈øtly met its merited fate.
Let all tho≈øe Indian traders claim,
Their ju≈øt reward, inglorious fame,
For vile ba≈øe and treacherous ends.
To Pollins, in the ≈øpring they ≈øent,
Much warlike ≈øtores, with an intent,
To carry them to our barbarous foes,
Expecting that no-body dare oppo≈øe,
A pre≈øent to their Indian friends.
A≈øtoni≈øh'd at the wild de≈øign,
Frontier inhabitants combin'd,
With brave ≈øouls, to ≈øtop their career,
Although ≈øome men apo≈øtatiz'd,
Who fir≈øt the grand attempt advis'd,
The bold frontiers they bravely ≈øtood,
To act for their king and their country's good,
In joint league, and ≈øtrangers to fear.
On March the fifth, in ≈øixty-five,
Their Indian pre≈øents did arrive,
In long pomp and cavalcade,
Near Sidelong Hill, where in di≈øgui≈øe,
Some patriots did their train ≈øurprize,
And quick as lightning tumbled ther loads,
And kindled them bonfires in the woods,
And mo≈øtly burnt their whole brigade.
At Loudon, when they heard the news,
They ≈øcarcely knew which way to choo≈øe,
For blind rage and di≈øcontent;
At length ≈øome ≈øoldiers they ≈øent out,
With guides for to conduct the route,
And ≈øeized ≈øome men that were trav'ling there,
And hurried them into Loudon where
They laid them fa≈øt with one con≈øent.
But men of re≈øolution thought,
Too much to ≈øee their neighbors caught,
For no crime but fal≈øe ≈øurmi≈øe;
Forthwith they join'd a warlike band,
And march'd to Loudon out of hand,
And kept the jailors pris'ners there,
Until our friends enlarged were,
Without fraud or any di≈øgui≈øe.
Let mankind cen≈øure or commend,
This ra≈øh performance in the end,
Then both ≈øides will find their account.
'Tis true no law can ju≈øtify,

div.p: After this we kept up a guard of men on the frontiers, for ≈øeveral months, to prevent ≈øupplies being ≈øent to the Indians, until it was proclaimed that Sir William John≈øon had made peace with them, and then we let the traders pa≈øs unmole≈øted.

In the year 1766, I heard that Sir William John≈øon, the king's agent for ≈øettling affairs with the Indians, had purcha≈øed from them all the land we≈øt of the Appalachion Mountains‚ñ™ that lay between the Chic and the Cherokee River; and as I knew by conver≈øing with the Indians in their own tongue, that there
was a large body of rich land there, I concluded I would take a tour we≈øtward, and explore that country.

I ≈øet out about the la≈øt of June, 1766, and went in the fir≈øt place to Hol≈øtein River, and from thence I travelled we≈øtward in company with Jo≈øhua Horton, Uriah Stone, William Baker, and James Smith, who came from near Carli≈øle. There was only four white men of us, and a mulatto ≈ølave about eighteen years of age, that Mr. Horton had with him. We explored the country ≈øouth of Kentucky, and there was no more ≈øign of white men there then, than there is now we≈øt of the head waters of the Mi≈ø≈øouri. We al≈øo explored Cumberland and Tenne≈ø≈øee Rivers, from Stone'sStone's River is a ≈øouth branch of Cumberland, and empties into it above Na≈øhville. We fir≈øt gave it this name in our journal in May 1767, after one of my fellow travellers, Mr. Uriah Stone, and I am told that it retains the ≈øame name unto this day. River down to the Ohio.

When we came to the mouth of Tenne≈ø≈øee, my fellow travellers concluded that they would proceeded on to the Illinois, and ≈øee ≈øome more of the land to the we≈øt:‚Äîthis I would not agree to. As I had already been longer from home than what I expectd, I thought my wife would be di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, and think I was killed by the Indians; therefore I concluded that I would return home. I ≈øent my hor≈øe with my fellow travellers to the Illinois, as it was difficult to take a hor≈øe through the mountains. My comrades gave me the greate≈øt part of the amunition they then had, which amounted only to half a pound of powder, and lead equivalent. Mr. Horton al≈øo lent me his mulatto boy, and I then ≈øet off through the wilderne≈øs, for Carolina.

About eight days after I left my company at the mouth of Tenne≈ø≈øee, on my journey ea≈øtward, I got a cane ≈øtab in my foot, which occa≈øioned my leg to ≈øwell, and I ≈øuffered much pain. I was now in a doleful ≈øituation‚Äîfar from any of the human ≈øpecies, excepting black Jamie, or the ≈øavages, and I knew not when I might meet with them‚Äîmy ca≈øe appeared de≈øperate, and I thought ≈øomething mu≈øt be done. All the ≈øurgical in≈øtruments I had, was a knife, a mocka≈øon awl, and a pair of bullit moulds‚Äîwith the≈øe I determined to draw the ≈ønag from my foot, if po≈ø≈øible. I ≈øtuck the awl in the ≈økin, and with the knife I cut the fle≈øh away from around the cane, and then I commanded the mulatto fellow to catch it with the bullit moulds, and pull it out, which he did. When I ≈øaw it, it ≈øeemed a ≈øhocking thing to be in any per≈øon's foot; it will therefore be ≈øuppo≈øed that I was very glad to have it out. The black fellow attended upon me, and obeyed my directions faithfully. I ordered him to ≈øearch for Indian medicine, and told him to get me a quantity of bark from the root of a lynn tree,
which I made him beat on a ≈øtone, with a tomahawk, and boil it in a kettle, and with the ooze I bathed my foot and leg:‚Äî what remained when I had fini≈øhed bathing, I boiled to a jelly, and made poultices thereof. As I had no rags, I made u≈øe of the green mo≈øs that grows upon logs, and wrapped it round with elm bark: by this means (≈øimple as it may ≈øeem) the ≈øwelling and inflamation in a great mea≈øure abated. As ≈øtormy weather appeared, I ordered Jamie to make us a ≈øhelter, which he did by erecting forks and poles, and covering them over with cane tops, like a fodder-hou≈øe. It was but about one hundred yards from a large buffaloe road. As we were almo≈øt out of provi≈øion, I commanded Jamie to take my gun, and I went along as well as I could, concealed my≈øelf near the road, and killed a buffaloe. When this was done, we jirkedJirk is a name well known by the hunters, and frontier inhabitants, for meat cut in ≈ømall pieces and laid on a ≈øcaffold, over a ≈ølow fire, whereby it is roa≈øted till it is thoroughly dry. the lean, and fryed the tallow out of the fat meat, which we kept to ≈øtew with our jirk as we needed it.
While I lay at this place, all the books I had to read, was a P≈øalm Book, and Watts upon Prayer. Whil≈øt in this ≈øituation I compo≈øed the following ver≈øes, which I then frequently ≈øung.

lg.l: Six weeks I've in this de≈øart been,
With one mulatto lad,
Excepting this poor ≈øtupid ≈ølave,
No company I had.
In ≈øolitude I here remain,
A cripple very ≈øore,
No friend or neighbor to be found‚ñ™
My ca≈øe for to deplore.
I'm far from home, far from the wife,
Which in my bo≈øom lay,
Far from my children dear, which u≈øed
Around me for to play.
This doleful circum≈øtance cannot
My happine≈øs prevent,
While peace of con≈øcience I enjoy,
Great comfort and content.

div.p:
I continued in this place until I could walk ≈ølowly, without crutches. As I now lay near a great buffaloe road, I was afraid that the Indians might be pa≈ø≈øing that way, and di≈øcover
any fire-place, therefore I moved off ≈øome di≈øtance, where I remained until I killed an elk. As my foot was yet ≈øore, I concluded that I would ≈øtay here until it was healed, le≈øt by travelling too ≈øoon it might again be inflamed.

In a few weeks after, I proceeded on, and in October I arrived in Carolina. I had now been eleven months in the wilderne≈øs, and during this time I neither ≈øaw bread, money, women, or ≈øpirituous liquors; and three months of which I ≈øaw none of the human ≈øpecies, except Jamie.

When I came into the ≈øettlement, my clothes were almo≈øt worn out, and the boy had nothing on him that ever was ≈øpun. He had buck-≈økin leggins, mocka≈øons and breech-clout‚Äîa bear-≈økin dre≈ø≈øed with the hair on, which he belted about him, and a racoon-≈økin cap. I had not travelled far after I came in before I was ≈øtrictly examined by the inhabitants. I told them the truth, and where I came from, &c. but my ≈øtory appeared ≈øo ≈øtrange to them, that they did not believe me. They ≈øaid they had never heard of any one coming through the mountains from the mouth of Tenne≈ø≈øee; and if any one would undertake ≈øuch a journey, ≈øurely no man would lend him his ≈ølave. They ≈øaid that they thought that all I had told them were lies, and on ≈øu≈øpicion they took me into cu≈øtody, and ≈øet a guard over me.

While I was confined here, I met with a reputable old acquaintance, who voluntarily became my voucher; and al≈øo told me of a number of my acquaintances that now lived near this place, who had moved from Penn≈øylvania‚ÄîOn this being made public, I was liberated. I went to a magi≈øtrate, and obtained a pa≈øs, and one of my old acquaintances made me a pre≈øent of a ≈øhirt. I then ca≈øt away my old rags, and all the clothes I now had was an old beaver hat, buck-≈økin leggins, mocka≈øons, and a new ≈øhirt; al≈øo an old blanket, which I commonly carried on my back in good weather. Being thus equipped, I marched on, with my white ≈øhirt loo≈øe, and Jamie with his bear-≈økin about him:‚Äîmy≈øelf appearing white, and Jamie very black, alarmed the dogs where-ever we came, ≈øo that they barked violently. The people frequently came out and a≈øked me where we came from, &c. I told them the truth, but they, for the mo≈øt part ≈øu≈øpected my ≈øtory, and I generally had to ≈øhew them my pa≈øs. In this way I came on to Fort Chi≈ø≈øel, where I left Jamie at Mr. Horton's negro-quarter, according to promi≈øe. I went from thence to Mr. George Adams's, on Reed Creek, where I had lodged, and where I had left my clothes as I was going out from home. When I dre≈ø≈øed my≈øelf in good clothes, and mounted on hor≈øeback, no man ever a≈øked me for a pa≈øs; therefore I concluded that a hor≈øe-thief, or even a robber, might pa≈øs
without interruption, provided he was only well dre≈ø≈øed, whereas the ≈øhabby villain would be immediately detected.

I returned home to Conococheague, in the fall 1767. When I arrived, I found that my wife and friends had de≈øpaired of ever ≈øeeing me again, as they had heard that I was killed by the Indians, and my hor≈øe brought into one of the Cherokee towns.

In the year 1769, the Indians again made incur≈øions on the frontiers; yet, the traders continued carrying goods and warlike ≈øtores to them. The frontiers took the alarm, and a number of per≈øons collected, de≈øtroyed and plundered a quantity of their powder, lead, &c. in Bedford county. Shortly after this, ≈øome of the≈øe per≈øons, with others, were apprehended and laid in irons in the guard-hou≈øe in Fort Bedford, on ≈øu≈øpicion of being the perpetrators of this crime.

Though I did not altogether approve of the conduct of this new club of black-boys, yet I concluded that they ≈øhould not lie in irons in the guard-hou≈øe, or remain in confinement, by arbitrary or military power. I re≈øolved therefore, if po≈ø≈øible, to relea≈øe them, if they even ≈øhould be tried by the civil law afterwards. I collected eighteen of my old black-boys, that I had ≈øeen tried in the Indian war, &c. I did not de≈øire a large party, le≈øt they ≈øhould be too much alarmed at Bedford, and accordingly prepare for us. We marched along the public road in day-light, and made no ≈øecret of our de≈øign:‚ÄîWe told tho≈øe whom we met, that we were going to take Fort Bedford, which appeared to them a very unlikely ≈øtory. Before this I made it known to one William Thomp≈øon, a man whom I could tru≈øt, and who lived there: him I employed as a ≈øpy, and ≈øent him along on hor≈øe-back, before, with orders to meet me at a certain place near Bedford, one hour before day. The next day a little before ≈øun-≈øet we encamped near the cro≈ø≈øings of Juniata, about fourteen miles from Bedford, and erected tents, as though we intended ≈øtaying all night, and not a man in my company knew to the contrary, ≈øave my≈øelf. Knowing that they would hear this in Bedford, and wi≈øhing it to be the ca≈øe, I thought to ≈øurprize them, by ≈øtealing a march.

As the moon ro≈øe about eleven o'clock, I ordered my boys to march, and we went on at the rate of five miles an hour, until we met Thomp≈øon at the place appointed. He told us that the commanding officer had frequently heard of us by travellers, and had ordered thirty men upon guard. He ≈øaid they knew our number, and only made game of the notion of eighteen men coming to re≈øcue the pri≈øoners, but they did not expect us until towards the middle of the day. I a≈øked him if the gate was open? He ≈øaid it was then ≈øhut, but he expected they would open it as u≈øual, at day-light, as they apprehended no
danger. I then moved my men privately up under the banks of Juniata, where we lay concealed about one hundred yards from the fort gate. I had ordered the men to keep a profound ≈øilence, until we got into it. I then ≈øent off Thomp≈øon again, to ≈øpy. At day-light he returned, and told us that the gate was open, and three centinels were ≈øtanding on the wall‚Äî that the guards were taking a morning dram, and the arms ≈øtanding together in one place. I then concluded to ru≈øh into the fort, and told Thomp≈øon to run before me to the arms. We ran with all our might, and as it was a mi≈øty morning, the centinels ≈øcarcely ≈øaw us until we were within the gate, and took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the arms. Ju≈øt as we were entering, two of them di≈øcharged their guns, though I do not believe they aimed at us. We then rai≈øed a ≈øhout, which ≈øurprized the town, though ≈øome of them were well plea≈øed with the news. We compelled a black-≈ømith to take the irons off the pri≈øoners, and then we left the place. This, I believe, was the fir≈øt Briti≈øh fort in America, that was taken by what they called American rebels.

Some time after this I took a journey we≈øtward, in order to ≈øurvey ≈øome located land I had on and near the Youhogany. As I pa≈ø≈øed near Bedford, while I was walking and leading my hor≈øe, I was overtaken by ≈øome men on hor≈øe-back, like travellers. One of them a≈øked my name, and on telling it, they immediately pulled out their pi≈øtols, and pre≈øented them at me, calling upon me to deliver my≈øelf, or I was a dead man. I ≈øtepped back, pre≈øented my rifle, and told them to ≈øtand off. One of them ≈ønapped a pi≈øtol at me, and another was preparing to ≈øhoot, when I fired my piece:‚Äîone of them al≈øo fired near the ≈øame time, and one of my fellow travellers fell. The a≈ø≈øailants then ru≈øhed up, and as my gun was empty, they took and tied me. I charged them with killing my fellow traveller, and told them he was a man that I had accidentally met with on the road, that had nothing to do with the public quarrel. They a≈ø≈øerted that I had killed him. I told them that my gun blowed, or made a ≈ølow fire‚Äîthat I had her from my face before ≈øhe went off, or I would not have mi≈ø≈øed my mark; and from the po≈øition my piece was in when it went off, it was not likely that my gun killed this man, yet I acknowledged I was not certain that it was not ≈øo. They then carried me to Bedford, laid me in irons in the guard-hou≈øe, ≈øummoned a jury of the opp≈øite party, and held an inque≈øt. The jury brought me in guilty of wilful murder. As they were afraid to keep me long in Bedford, for fear of a re≈øcue, they ≈øent me privately through the wilderne≈øs to Carli≈øle, where I was laid in heavy irons.

Shortly after I came here, we heard that a number of my old black boys were coming to tear down the jail. I told the ≈øheriff that I would not be re≈øcued, as I knew that the indictment was wrong; therefore I wi≈øhed to ≈øtand my trial. As I had found the black boys to be always under good command, I expected I could prevail on them to return, and therefore wi≈øhed to write to them‚Äîto this the ≈øheriff readily agreed. I wrote a letter to them, with irons on my hands, which was immediately ≈øent; but as they had heard that I was in irons, they would come on. When we heard they were near the town, I told the ≈øheriff I would ≈øpeak to them out of the window, and if the irons were off, I made no doubt but I could prevail on them to de≈øi≈øt. The ≈øheriff ordered them to be taken off, and ju≈øt as they were taken off my hands, the black boys came running up to the jail. I went to the window and called to them, and they gave attention. I thanked them for their kind intentions, and told them the greate≈øt favor they could confer upon me, would be to grant me this one reque≈øt, to withdraw from the jail, and return in peace: to this they complied, and withdrew. While I was ≈øpeaking, the irons were taken off my feet, and never again put on.

Before this party arrived at Conococheague, they met about three hundred more, on the way, coming to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and were re≈øolved to take me out; they then turned, and all came together, to Carli≈øle. The rea≈øon they gave for coming again, was, becau≈øe they thought that government was ≈øo enraged at me that I would not get a fair trial; but my friends and my≈øelf together again prevailed on them to return in peace.

James Smith, John≈øon and Moorhead, taking along the other road, were met by John Holmes e≈øq. to whom James Smith ≈øpoke in a friendly manner, but received no an≈øwer. Mr. Holmes ha≈øted, and gave an alarm in Bedford, from whence a party of men were ≈øent in pur≈øuit of them; but Smith and his companions not having the lea≈øt thought of any ≈øuch mea≈øures being taken, (why ≈øhould they?) travelled ≈ølowly on. After they had gained the place where the roads joined, they delayed until the other part of their company ≈øhould come up. At this time a number of men came riding, like men travelling; they a≈øked Smith his name, which he told them‚Äîon which they immediately a≈ø≈øaulted him as highway-men, and with pre≈øented pi≈øtols, commanded him to ≈øurrender, or he was a dead man; upon which Smith ≈øtepped back, a≈øked them if they were highway-men, charging them at the ≈øame time to ≈øtand off, when immediately, Robert George (one of the a≈ø≈øailants) ≈ønapped a pi≈øtol at Smith's head, and that before Smith offered to ≈øhoot, (which ≈øaid George him≈øelf acknowled upon oath;) whereupon Smith pre≈øented his gun at another of the a≈ø≈øailants, who was preparing to ≈øhoot him with his pi≈øtol. After which Smith was taken and carried into Bedford, where John Holmes, e≈øq. the informer, held an inque≈øt on the corp≈øe, one of the a≈ø≈øailants being as an evidence, (nor was there any other troubled about the matter) Smith was brought in guilty of wilful murder, and ≈øo committed to pri≈øon. But a jealou≈øy ari≈øing in the brea≈øts of many that the inque≈øt, either through inadvertency, ignorance or ≈øome other default, was not ≈øo fair as it ought to be; William Deny, corroner of the county, upon requi≈øion made, thought proper to re-examine the matter, and ≈øummoning a jury of unexceptionable men, out of three town≈øhips‚Äîmen who≈øe candor, probity and hone≈øty, is unque≈øtionable with all who are acquainted with them, and having rai≈øed the corp≈øe, held an inque≈øt in a ≈øolemn manner, during three days. In the cour≈øe of their ≈øcrutiny they found John≈øon's ≈øhirt blacked about the bullit-hole, by the powder of the charge by which he was killed, whereupon they examined into the di≈øtance Smith ≈øtood from John≈øon when he ≈øhot, and one of the a≈ø≈øailants being admitted to oath, ≈øwore to the re≈øpective ≈øpots of ground they both ≈øtood on at that time, which the jury mea≈øured, and found to be twenty-three feet, nearly; then trying the experiment of ≈øhooting at the ≈øame ≈øhirt, both with and again≈øt the wind, and at the ≈øame di≈øtance, found no effects, not the lea≈øt ≈øtain from the powder, on the ≈øhirt:‚ÄîAnd let any per≈øon that plea≈øes, make the experiment, and I will venture to affirm he ≈øhall find that powder will not ≈øtain at half the di≈øtance above mentioned, if ≈øhot out of a rifle gun, which Smith's was. I have now repre≈øented the matter in its true and genuine colors, and which I will abide by. I only beg liberty to make a few remarks and reflections on the above mentioned extract. The author ≈øays "James Smith, with two others in company, pa≈ø≈øed round the town, without touching," by which it is plain he would in≈øinuate, and make the public believe that Smith, and that part of the company, had taken ≈øome bye road, which is utterly fal≈øe, for it was the king's high-way, and the ≈øtraighte≈øt, that through Bedford, being ≈øomething to the one ≈øide, nor would the other part of the company have gone through the town, but for the rea≈øon already given. I earne≈øtly urge the above caution, as I have known very remarkable and grievous errors of this kind. You are to encamp on the hollow ≈øquare, except the volunteers, who, according to their own reque≈øt, are to encamp on the front of the ≈øquare. A ≈øufficient number of centinels are to be kept round the ≈øquare, at a proper di≈øtance. Every man is to be under arms at the break of day, and to parade oppo≈øite to their fire-places, facing out, and when the officers examine their arms, and find them in good order, and give nece≈ø≈øary directions, they are to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, with orders to have their arms near them, and be always in readine≈øs.

In this manner we proceeded on, to French Creek, where we found the Indian town evacuated. I then went on further than my orders called for, in que≈øt of Indians; but our provi≈øions being nearly exhau≈øted, we were obliged to return. On
our way back, we met with con≈øiderable difficulties on account of high waters and ≈øcarcity of provi≈øion; yet we never lo≈øt one hor≈øe, excepting ≈øome that gave out.

After peace was made with the Indians, I met with ≈øome of them in Pitt≈øburg, and enquired of them in their own tongue, concerning this expedition,‚Äînot letting them know I was there. They told me that they watched the movements of this army ever after they had left Fort-Pitt, and as they pa≈ø≈øed thro the glades or barrens they had a full view of them from the adjacent hills and computed their number to be be about one thou≈øand. They ≈øaid they al≈øo examined their camps, both before and after they were gone, and found, they could not make an advantageous attack, and therefore moved off from their town and hunting ground before we arrived.

In the year 1788 I ≈øettled in Bourbon county, Kentucky, ≈øeven miles above Paris; and in the ≈øame year was elected a member of the convention, that ≈øat at Danville, to confer about a ≈øeparation from the ≈øtate of Virginia.‚Äîand from that year until the year 1799, I repre≈øented Bourbon county, either in convention or as a member of the general a≈ø≈øembly, except two years that I was left a few votes behind.

div.head: ON THE MANNERS AND CUSTOMS OF THE INDIANS.
div.p:
The Indians are a ≈ølovenly people in their dre≈øs.‚ÄîThey ≈øeldom ever wa≈øh their ≈øhirts, and in regard to cookery they are exceeding filthy. When they kill a buffaloe they will ≈øometimes la≈øh the paunch of it round a ≈øapling, and ca≈øt it into the kettle, boil it and ≈øup the broth; tho they commonly ≈øhake it about in cold water, then boil and eat it.‚ÄîNotwith≈øtanding all this, they are very polite in their own way, and they retain among them, the e≈ø≈øentials of good manners; tho they have few compliments, yet they are complai≈øant to one another, and when accompanied with good humour and di≈øcretion, they entertain ≈øtrangers in the be≈øt manner their circum≈øtances will admit. They u≈øe but few titles of honor. In the military line, the titles of great men are only captains or leaders of parties‚ÄîIn the civil line, the titles are only councilors, chiefs or the old wi≈øemen. The≈øe titles are never made u≈øe of in addre≈ø≈øing any of their great men. The language commonly made u≈øe of in addre≈ø≈øing them, is, Grandfather, Father, or Uncle. They have no ≈øuch thing in u≈øe among them, as Sir, Mr. Madam or Mi≈øtre≈øs‚ÄîThe common mode of addre≈øs, is, my Friend, Brother, Cou≈øin, or Mother Si≈øter, &c. They pay great re≈øpect to age; or to the
aged Fathers and Mothers among them of every rank. No one can arrive at any place of honor, among them, but by merit. Either ≈øome exploit in war, mu≈øt be performed, before any one can be advanced in the military line, or become eminent for wi≈ødom before they can obtain a ≈øeat in council. It would appear to the Indians a mo≈øt ridiculous thing to ≈øee a man lead off a company of warriors, as an officer, who had him≈øelf never been in a battle in his life: even in ca≈øe of merit, they are ≈ølow in advancing any one, until they arrive at or near middle-age.

They invite every one that comes to their hou≈øe, or camp to eat, while they have any thing to give; and it is accounted bad manners to refu≈øe eating, when invited. They are very tenacious of their old mode of dre≈ø≈øing and painting, and do not change their fa≈øhions as we do. They are very fond of tobacco, and the men almo≈øt all ≈ømoke it mixed with ≈øumach leaves or red willow bark, pulverized; tho they ≈øeldom u≈øe it any other way. They make u≈øe of the pipe al≈øo as a token of love and friend≈øhip.

In court≈øhip they al≈øo differ from us. It is a common thing among them for a young woman, if in love, to make ≈øuit to a young man: tho the fir≈øt addre≈øs may be by the man; yet the other is the mo≈øt common. The ≈øquaws are generally very immode≈øt in their words and actions, and will often put the young men to the blu≈øh. The men commonly appear to be po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of much more mode≈øty than the women; yet I have been acquainted with ≈øome young ≈øquaws that appeared really mode≈øt: genuine it mu≈øt be, as they were under very little re≈øtraint in the channel of education or cu≈øtom.

When the Indians meet one-another, in≈øtead of ≈øaying, how do you do, they commonly ≈øalute in the following manner‚Äîyou are my friend‚Äîthe reply is, truly friend, I am your friend,‚Äîor, cou≈øin, you yet exi≈øt‚Äîthe reply is certainly I do.‚ÄîThey have their children under tolerable command: ≈øeldom ever whip them, and their common mode of cha≈øti≈øing, is by ducking them in cold water; therefore their children are more obedient in the winter ≈øea≈øon, than they are in the ≈øummer; tho they are then not ≈øo often ducked. They are a peaceable people, and ≈øcarcely ever wrangle or ≈øcold, when ≈øober; but they are very much addicted to drinking, and men and women will become ba≈øely intoxicated, if they can, by any means, procure or obtain ≈øpirituous liquor; and then they are commonly either extremely merry and kind, or very turbulent, ill-humoured and di≈øorderly.

div.head: ON THEIR TRADITIONS AND RELIGIOUS SENTIMENTS.
div.p:
As the family that I was adopted into was intermarried with the Wiandots and Ottawas, three tongues were commonly ≈øpoke
viz. Caughnewaga, or what the French call Iroque, al≈øo the Wiandot and Ottawa; by this means I had an opportunity of learning the≈øe three tongues; and I found that the≈øe nations varied in their traditions and opinions concerning religion;‚Äî and even numbers of the ≈øame nations differed widely in their religious ≈øentiments. Their traditions are vague, whim≈øical, romantic and many of them ≈øcarce worth relating; and not any of them reach back to the creation of the world. The Wiandots comes the neare≈øt to this. They tell of a ≈øquaw that was found when an infant, in the water in a canoe made of bull-ru≈øhes: this ≈øquaw became a great prophetre≈øs and did many wonderful things; ≈øhe turned water into dry land, and at length made this continent, which was, at that time, only a very ≈ømall i≈øland, and but a few Indians in it. Tho they were then but few they had not ≈øufficient room to hunt; therefore this ≈øquaw went to the water ≈øide, and prayed that this little i≈øland might be enlarged. The great being then heard her prayer, and ≈øent great numbers of Water Tortoi≈øes, and Mu≈økrats, which brought with them mud and other materials, for enlarging this i≈øland, and by this means, they ≈øay, it was encrea≈øed to the ≈øize that it now remains; therefore they ≈øay, that the white people ought not to encroach upon them, or take their land from them, becau≈øe their great grand mother made it.‚ÄîThey ≈øay, that about this time the angels or heavenly inhabitants, as they call them, frequently vi≈øited them and talked with their forefathers; and gave directions how to pray, and how to appea≈øe the great being when he was offended. They told them they were to offer ≈øacrifice, burn tobacco, buffaloe and deer bones; but that they were not to burn bears or racoons bones in ≈øacrifice.

The Ottawas ≈øay, that there are two great beings that rule and govern the univer≈øe, who are at war with each other; the one they call Maneto, and the other Matchemaneto. They ≈øay that Maneto is all kindne≈øs and love, and that Matchemaneto is an evil ≈øpirit, that delights in doing mi≈øchief; and ≈øome of them think, that they are equal in power, and therefore wor≈øhip the evil ≈øpirit out of a principle of fear. Others doubt which of the two may be the mo≈øt powerful, and therefore endeavour to keep in favour with both, by giving each of them ≈øome kind of wor≈øhip. Others ≈øay that Maneto is the fir≈øt great cau≈øe and therefore mu≈øt be all powerful and ≈øupreme, and ought to be adored and wor≈øhipped; whereas Matchemaneto ought to be rejected and di≈øpi≈øed.

Tho≈øe of the Ottawas that wor≈øhip the evil ≈øpirit, pretend to be great conjurors. I think if there is any ≈øuch thing now in the world as witchcraft, it is among the≈øe people, I have been told wonderful ≈øtories concerning their proceedings; but never
was ye witne≈øs to any thing that appeared evidently ≈øupernatural.

Some of the Wiandots and Caughnewagas profe≈øs to be Roman-catholics; but even the≈øe retain many of the notions of their ance≈øtors. Tho≈øe of them who reject the Roman-catholic religion, hold that there is one great fir≈øt cau≈øe, whom they call Owan ‚Ä¢ eya, that rules and governs the univer≈øe, and takes care of all his creatures, rational and irrational, and gives them their food in due ≈øea≈øon, and hears the prayers of all tho≈øe that call upon him; therefore it is but ju≈øt and rea≈øonable to pray, and offer ≈øacrifice to this great being, and to do tho≈øe things that are plea≈øing in his ≈øight;‚Äîbut they differ widely in what is plea≈øing or di≈øplea≈øing to this great being. Some hold that following nature or their own propen≈øities is the way to happine≈øs, and cannot be di≈øplea≈øing to the deity, becau≈øe he delights in the happine≈øs of his creatures, and does nothing in vain; but gave tho≈øe di≈øpo≈øitions with a de≈øign to lead to happine≈øs, and therefore they ought to be followed. Others reject this opinion altogether, and ≈øay that following their own propen≈øities in this manner, is neither the means of happine≈øs nor the way to plea≈øe the deity.

Tecaughretanego was of opinion that following nature in a limited ≈øen≈øe was rea≈øonable and right. He ≈øaid that mo≈øt of the irrational animals by following their natural propen≈øities, were led to the greate≈øt pitch of happine≈øs that their natures and the world they lived in would admit of. He ≈øaid that mankind and the rattle ≈ønakes had evil di≈øpo≈øitions, that led them to injure them≈øelves and others. He gave in≈øtances of this. He ≈øaid he had a puppy that he did not intend to rai≈øe, and in order to try an experiment, he tyed this puppy on a pole and held it to a rattle ≈ønake, which bit it ≈øeveral times; that he ob≈øerved the ≈ønake ≈øhortly after, rolling about apparently in great mi≈øery, ≈øo that it appeared to have poi≈øoned it≈øelf as well as the puppy. The other in≈øtance he gave was concerning him≈øelf. He ≈øaid that when he was a young man, he was very fond of the women, and at length got the venereal di≈øea≈øe, ≈øo that by following this propen≈øity, he was led to injure him≈øelf and others. He ≈øaid our happine≈øs depends on our u≈øing our rea≈øon, in order to ≈øuppre≈øs the≈øe evil di≈øpo≈øitions; but when our propen≈øities neither lead us to injure our≈øelves nor others, we might with ≈øafety indulge them, or even pur≈øu≈øe them as the means of happine≈øs.

The Indians generally, are of opinion that there are great numbers of inferior Deities, which they call Carreyagaroona, which ≈øignifies the Heavenly Inhabitants. The≈øe beings they ≈øuppo≈øe are employed as a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, in managing the affairs of the
univer≈øe, and in in≈øpecting the actions of men: and that even the irrational animals are engaged in viewing their actions, and bearing intelligence to the Gods. The eagle, for this purpo≈øe, with her keen eye, is ≈øoaring about in the day, and the owl, with her nightly eye, perched on the trees around their camp in the night; therefore, when they ob≈øerve the eagle or the owl near, they immediately offer ≈øacrifice, or burn tobacco, that they may have a good report to carry to the Gods. They ≈øay that there are al≈øo great numbers of evil ≈øpirits, which they call Onasabroona, which ≈øignifies the Inhabiants of the Lower Region. The≈øe they ≈øay are employed in di≈øturbing the world, and the good ≈øpirits are always going after them, and ≈øetting things right, ≈øo that they are con≈øtantly working in oppo≈øition to each other. Some talk of a future ≈øtate, but not with any certainty: at be≈øt their notions are vague and un≈øettled. Others deny a future ≈øtate altogether, and ≈øay that after death they neither think or live.

As the Caugnewagas and the ≈øix nations ≈øpeak nearly the ≈øame language, their theology is al≈øo nearly alike. When I met with the Shawanees or Delawares, as I could not ≈øpeak their tongue, I ≈øpoke Ottawa to them, and as it bore ≈øome re≈øemblance to their language, we under≈øtood each other in ≈øome common affairs, but as I could only conver≈øe with them very imperfectly, I cannot from my own knowledge, with certainty, give any account of their theological opinions.

div.head: ON THEIR POLICE, OR CIVIL GOVERNMENT.
div.p: I have often heard of Indian Kings, but never ≈øaw any.‚Äî How any term u≈øed by the Indians in their own tongue, for the chief man of a nation, could be rendered King, I know not. The chief of a nation is neither a ≈øupreme ruler, monarch or potentate‚ÄîHe can neither make war or peace, leagues or treaties‚ÄîHe cannot impre≈øs ≈øoldiers, or di≈øpo≈øe of magazines‚ÄîHe cannot adjourn, prorogue or di≈ø≈øolve a general a≈ø≈øembly, nor can he refu≈øe his a≈ø≈øent to their conclu≈øions, or in any manner controul them‚ÄîWith them there is no ≈øuch thing as hereditary ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, title of nobility or royal blood, even talked of‚ÄîThe chief of a nation, even with the con≈øent of his a≈ø≈øembly, or council, cannot rai≈øe one ≈øhilling of tax off the citizens, but only receive what they plea≈øe to give as free and voluntary donations‚ÄîThe chief of a nation has to hunt for his living, as any other citizen‚ÄîHow then can they with any propriety, be called kings? I apprehend that the white people were formerly ≈øo fond of the name of kings, and ≈øo ignorant of their power, that they concluded the chief man of a nation mu≈øt be a king.

As they are illiterate, they con≈øequently have no written
code of laws. What they execute as laws, are either old cu≈øtoms, or the immediate re≈øult of new councils. Some of their ancient laws or cu≈øtoms are very pernicious, and di≈øturb the public weal. Their vague law of marriage is a glaring in≈øtance of this, as the man and his wife are under no legal obligation to live together, if they are both willing to part. They have little form, or ceremony among them, in matrimony, but do like the I≈øraelites of old‚Äîthe man goes in unto the woman, and ≈øhe becomes his wife. The years of puberty and the age of con≈øent, is about fourteen for the women, and eighteen for the men. Before I was taken by the Indians, I had often heard that in the ceremony of marriage, the man gave the woman a deer's leg, and ≈øhe gave him a red ear of corn, ≈øignifying that ≈øhe was to keep him in bread, and he was to keep her in meat. I enquired of them concerning the truth of this, and they ≈øaid they knew nothing of it, further than that they had heard it was the ancient cu≈øtom among ≈øome nations. Their frequent changing of partners prevents propagation, creates di≈øturbances, and often occa≈øions murder and blood≈øhed; though this is commonly committed under the pretence of being drunk. Their impunity to crimes committed when intoxicated with ≈øpirituous liquors, or their admitting one crime as an excu≈øe for another, is a very unju≈øt law or cu≈øtom.

The extremes they run into in dividing the necece≈ø≈øaries of life, are hurtful to the public weal; though their dividing meat when hunting, may an≈øwer a valuable purpo≈øe, as one family may have ≈øucce≈øs one day, and the other the next; but their carrying this cu≈øtom to the town, or to agriculture, is ≈øtriking at the root of indu≈øtry, as indu≈øtrious per≈øons ought to be rewarded, and the lazy ≈øuffer for their indolence.

They have ≈øcarcely any penal laws: the principal puni≈øhment is degrading: even murder is not puni≈øhed by any formal law, only the friends of the murdered are at liberty to ≈ølay the murderer, if ≈øome attonement is not made. Their not annexing penalties to their laws, is perhaps not as great a crime, or as unju≈øt and cruel, as the bloody penal laws of England, which we have ≈øo long ≈øhamefully practi≈øed, and which are in force in this ≈øtate, until our penitentiary hou≈øe is fini≈øhed, which is now building, and then they are to be repealed.

Let us al≈øo take a view of the advantages attending Indian police:‚ÄîThey are not oppre≈ø≈øed or perplexed with expen≈øive litigation‚ÄîThey are not injured by legal robbery‚ÄîThey have no ≈øplendid villains that make them≈øelves grand and great upon other peoples labor‚ÄîThey have neither church or ≈øtate erected as money-making machines.

div.head: ON THEIR DISCIPLINE, AND METHOD OF WAR.
div.p:
I have often heard the Briti≈øh officers call the Indians the undi≈øciplined ≈øavages, which is a capital mi≈øtake‚Äîas they have all the e≈ø≈øentials of di≈øcipline. They are under good command, and punctual in obeying orders: they can act in concert, and when their officers lay a plan and give orders, they will chearfully unite in putting all their directions into immediate execution; and by each man ob≈øerving the motion or movement of his right hand companion, they can communicate the motion from right to left, and march a-brea≈øt in concert, and in ≈øcattered order, though the line may be more than a mile long, and continue, if occa≈øion requires, for a con≈øiderable di≈øtance, without di≈øorder or confu≈øion. They can perform various nece≈ø≈øary manoeuvres, either ≈ølowly, or as fa≈øt as they can run: they can form a circle, or ≈øemi-circle: the circle they make u≈øe of, in order to ≈øurround their enemy, and the ≈øemi-circle if the enemy has a river on one ≈øide of them. They can al≈øo form a large hollow ≈øquare, face out and take trees: this they do, if their enemies are about ≈øurrounding them, to prevent being ≈øhot from either ≈øide of the tree. When they go into battle they are not loaded or encumbered with many clothes, as they commonly fight naked, ≈øave only breech-clout, leggins and mocke≈øons. There is no ≈øuch thing as corporeal puni≈øhment u≈øed, in order to bring them under ≈øuch good di≈øcipline: degrading is the only cha≈øti≈øement, and they are ≈øo unanimous in this, that it effectually an≈øwers the purpo≈øe. Their officers plan, order and conduct matters until they are brought into action, and then each man is to fight as though he was to gain the battle him≈øelf. General orders are commonly given in time of battle, either to advance or retreat, and is done by a ≈øhout or yell, which is well under≈øtood, and then they retreat or advance in concert. They are generally well equipped, and exceeding expert and active in the u≈øe of arms. Could it be ≈øuppo≈øed that undi≈øciplined troops could defeat Generals Braddock, Grant, &c? It may be ≈øaid by ≈øome that the French were al≈øo engaged in this war: true, they were; yet I know it was the Indians that laid the plan, and with ≈ømall a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, put it into execution. The Indians had no aid from the French, or any other power, when they be≈øieged Fort Pitt in the year 1763, and cut off the communication for a con≈øiderable time, between that po≈øt and Fort Loudon, and would have defeated General Bouquet's army, (who were on the way to rai≈øe the ≈øiege) had it not been for the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Virginia volunteers. They had no Briti≈øh troops with them when they defeated Colonel Crawford, near the Sandu≈øky, in the time of the American War with Great Britain; or when they defeated
Colonel Loughrie, on the Ohio, near the Miami, on his way to meet General Clarke: this was al≈øo in the time of the Briti≈øh war. It was the Indians alone that defeated Colonel Todd, in Kentucky, near the Blue licks‚ñ™ in the year 1782; and Colonel Harmer, betwixt the Ohio and Lake Erie, in the year 1790, and General St. Clair, in the year 1791; and it is ≈øaid that there were more of our men killed at this defeat, than there were in any one battle during our conte≈øt with Great Britain. They had no aid when they fought even the Virginia rifle-men almo≈øt a whole day, at the Great Kanhawa, in the year 1774; and when they found they could not prevail again≈øt the Virginians, they made a mo≈øt artful retreat. Notwith≈øtanding they had the Ohio to cro≈øs, ≈øome continued firing, whil≈øt others were cro≈ø≈øing the river; in this manner they proceeded until they all got over, before the Virginians knew that they had retreated; and in this retreat they carried off all their wounded. In the mo≈øt of the foregoing defeats, they fought with an inferior number, though in this, I believe it was not the ca≈øe.

Nothing can be more unju≈øtly repre≈øented than the different accounts we have had of their number from time to time, both by their own computations, and that of the Briti≈øh. While I was among them, I ≈øaw the account of the number, that they in tho≈øe parts gave to the French, and kept it by me. When they in their own council-hou≈øe, were taking an account of their number, with a piece of bark newly ≈øtripped, and a ≈ømall ≈øtick, which an≈øwered the end of a ≈ølate and pencil, I took an account of the different nations and tribes, which I added together, and found there were not half the number which they had given the French: and though they were then their allies, and lived among them, it was not ea≈øy finding out the deception, as they were a wandering ≈øet, and ≈øome of them almo≈øt always in the woods hunting. I a≈øked one of the chiefs what was their rea≈øon for making ≈øuch different returns? He ≈øaid it was for political rea≈øons, in order to obtain greater pre≈øents from the French, by telling them they could not divide ≈øuch and ≈øuch quantities of goods among ≈øo many.

In year of General Bouquet's la≈øt campaign, 1764, I ≈øaw the official return made by the Briti≈øh officers, of the number of Indians that were in arms again≈øt us that year, which amounted to thirty thou≈øand. As I was then a lieutenant in the Briti≈øh ≈øervice, I told them I was of opinion that there was not above one thou≈øand in arms again≈øt us, as they were divided by Broad-≈øtreet's army being then at Lake Erie. The Briti≈øh officers hooted at me, and ≈øaid they could not make England ≈øen≈øible of the difficulties they labored under in fighting them, as England expect that their troops could fight the undi≈øciplined ≈øavages
in America, five to one, as they did the Ea≈øt-Indians, and therefore my report would not an≈øwer their purpo≈øe, as they could not give an honorable account of the war, but by augmenting their number. I am of opinion that from Braddock's war, until the pre≈øent time, there never were more than three thou≈øand Indians at any time, in arms again≈øt us, we≈øt of Fort Pitt, and frequently not half that number. According to the Indians' own accounts, during the whole of Braddock's war, or from 1755, till 1758, they killed or took, fifty of our people, for one that they lo≈øt. In the war that commenced in the year 1763, they killed, comparatively, few of our people, and lo≈øt more of theirs, as the frontiers (e≈øpecially the Virginians) had learned ≈øomething of their method of war: yet, they, in this war, according to their own accounts, (which I believe to be true) killed or took ten of our people, for one they lo≈øt.
